target:
The U.S. Attorney's Office in the Southern District of New indicted New York City Mayor Eric Adams for alleged corruption in September 2024, but after President Trump took office, his Department of Justice directed that charges be dropped.  Acting Deputy Attorney General Emil Bove said the prosecution “unduly restricted” the mayor’s ability to “devote full attention and resources to the illegal immigration and violent crime that has escalated under the policies of the prior Administration.”

Several DOJ leaders resigned rather than accept this instruction; the interim US attorney for the Southern District, Danielle Sassoon (a Republican), resigned, stating that the proposed dismissal was an illegitimate exchange for Adams' help with Trump’s immigration policy. According to press reports [https://www.cnn.com/politics/live-news/trump-administration-russia-ukraine-02-18-25#cm7allb71000h3b6neqhr3n87], seven other DOJ officials also resigned, some immediately and others within the next several days.

Bove's responsive letter to Sassoon accused her of “disobeying direct orders implementing the policy of a duly elected President” and “pursuing a politically motivated prosecution despite an express instruction to dismiss the case. You lost sight of the oath that you took when you started at the Department of Justice.”

On Feb. 14, 2025, Bove and two other prosecutors signed the request to the court to drop charges (without prejudice to their being refiled in the future).  This request is under consideration by the court; the case is before Judge Dale Ho. Some former prosecutors and the organization Common Cause have sought to be heard on the appropriate next steps, opposing dismissal. A hearing is scheduled for Feb. 19, 2025; Judge Ho has asked the parties to "be prepared to address, inter alia, the reasons for the Government’s motion, the scope and effect of Mayor Adams’s “consent[] in writing,” and the procedure for resolution of the motion."

On Feb. 21, 2025, the court cancelled the scheduled trial, and--because the government and the defendant were in agreement about dismissing charges--appointed Paul Clement as amicus curiae to present additional arguments on the Government's Motion to Dismiss. Clement had served as U.S. Solicitor General in the George W. Bush Administration.  His brief, filed March 7, took the position that the case should be dismissed--but with prejudice (that is, closing off the possibility of it being refiled) to avoid giving the federal government ongoing leverage over Mayor Adams' activities.  He wrote: "“A dismissal without prejudice creates a palpable sense that the prosecution outlined in the indictment and approved by a grand jury could be renewed, a prospect that hangs like the proverbial sword of Damocles over the accused."

In the meanwhile, the defendant filed a motion asking the court for exactly the outcome Clement subsequently recommended--to dismiss his indictment with prejudice.

On April 2, 2025, the court issued its final opinion and order dismissing the case. The court dismissed the case with prejudice, finding that "dismissing the case without prejudice would create the perception that the Mayor's freedom depends on his ability to carry out the immigration enforcement priorities of the administration, and that he might be more beholden to the demands of the federal government than to the wishes of his own constituents." Further, the court found that any "appearances of impropriety" in the case were pretextual and unmerited, waving away any concerns that any party had improper motives in dismissing the case. This result thus prevents any future suit alleging the same facts from being brought against the Mayor.

This case is now closed.

A hearing is scheduled for Feb. 19, 2025; Judge Ho has asked the parties to "be prepared to address, inter alia, the reasons for the Government’s motion, the scope and effect of Mayor Adams’s “consent[] in writing,” and the procedure for resolution of the motion."

On Feb. 21, 2025, the court cancelled the scheduled trial, and--because the government and the defendant were in agreement about dismissing charges--appointed Paul Clement as amicus curiae to present additional arguments on the Government's Motion to Dismiss. Clement had served as U.S. Solicitor General in the George W. Bush Administration.  His brief, filed March 7, took the position that the case should be dismissed--but with prejudice (that is, closing off the possibility of it being refiled) to avoid giving the federal government ongoing leverage over Mayor Adams' activities.  He wrote: "“A dismissal without prejudice creates a palpable sense that the prosecution outlined in the indictment and approved by a grand jury could be renewed, a prospect that hangs like the proverbial sword of Damocles over the accused."

In the meanwhile, the defendant filed a motion asking the court for exactly the outcome Clement subsequently recommended--to dismiss his indictment with prejudice.

On April 2, 2025, the court issued its final opinion and order dismissing the case. The court dismissed the case with prejudice, finding that "dismissing the case without prejudice would create the perception that the Mayor's freedom depends on his ability to carry out the immigration enforcement priorities of the administration, and that he might be more beholden to the demands of the federal government than to the wishes of his own constituents." Further, the court found that any "appearances of impropriety" in the case were pretextual and unmerited, waving away any concerns that any party had improper motives in dismissing the case. This result thus prevents any future suit alleging the same facts from being brought against the Mayor.

This case is now closed.

annotation.explanation: The case is closed.
